Osteoarthritis of the knee_1:
Patient Description 1:
    
    A 64-year-old male patient presented with chronic knee pain localized to the medial aspect of the right knee, which he described as 7/10 in intensity, exacerbated by weight-bearing activities and prolonged standing. The pain is often accompanied by stiffness, especially in the morning or after prolonged sitting, and he reported occasional episodes of knee swelling. These symptoms have gradually worsened over the past three years, impacting his ability to walk and perform routine activities. The patient has a history of prolonged occupational standing as a construction worker. Physical examination revealed crepitus on knee movement, limited range of motion, and joint line tenderness. The severity of osteoarthritis is a crucial factor in the diagnostic evaluation of this case.
Osteoarthritis of the knee_2:
Patient Description 2:
    
    A 72-year-old female patient presented with bilateral knee symptoms. She described a constant, dull knee pain, rated as 5/10 in intensity, localized to both knees. The pain is often associated with a feeling of stiffness and occasional swelling in the knee joints. The patient reported difficulty in walking long distances and performing household chores due to her knee symptoms, which have been gradually progressing over the last five years. Her medical history is significant for obesity, with a body mass index of 32 kg/m². On examination, both knees exhibited crepitus, limited range of motion, and signs of joint effusion. The severity of osteoarthritis will be a critical factor in the diagnostic assessment for this patient.
Osteoarthritis of the knee_3:
Patient Description 3:
    
    An 60-year-old male patient presented with persistent right knee pain, which he described as 6/10 in intensity, localized to the anterior aspect of the knee joint. The pain is exacerbated by weight-bearing activities and prolonged walking, and the patient reported a sensation of stiffness, particularly in the morning. He has noted intermittent episodes of knee swelling as well. The symptoms have been ongoing for the past four years and have progressively worsened. The patient has a history of recurrent knee injuries from playing sports during his youth. Physical examination revealed tenderness, crepitus, and reduced range of motion in the right knee. The severity of osteoarthritis is an essential consideration in the diagnostic evaluation for this case.
